item.title: CPU
item.description: Abstract Â§ 2 Main Components - ALU, Control Unit Fire the necessary components based on the given Instruction Start in Kernel Mode. Before executing a program, the kernel initiates the switch to User Mode Benefits Â§ Optmised for computation that requires sequential execution(One Instruction after another Instruction), Branching and logic Terminologies Â§ 32-bit Â§ Width that are 32 bits each 64-bit Â§ Width that are 32 bits each Scratch Area Â§ A small amount of high-speed memory that is used to store temporary data Typically located on the CPU die itself Core Â§ One single unit of CPU that executes Instruction independently from other cores .

item.title: Multi-threading
item.description: Abstract Â§ Also known as Hyper-threading A mechanism achieved with wither Multi-threaded Chip(true Parallelism (å¹¶è¡Œæ€§)) or quick Context Switch(Concurrency (å¹¶å‘)) or both Doesnâ€™t offer true Parallelism (å¹¶è¡Œæ€§) on Single-Core CPU which only supports one Process running at a time Thread-switching time is reduced to nanosecond To users, CPU Speed is divided by the total number of Thread executing at the same time when multiple Thread sharing the same Core Performance is a fine balance between performance gains from each Thread and Overhead of Creating Thread Benefits Â§ Improved Responsiveness Â§ Can continue to run other Thread while waiting for I/O operations to complete Run other Thread while one Thread is waiting Improved Performance Â§ When tasks are stateless, independent of each other & long waiting time incurs in the task Cons Â§ More likely to get Race Condition (ç«æ€æ¡ä»¶) Â§ Where there is a shared resource More likely to get Deadlock (æ­»é”) Â§ Where there is a shared resource Overhead of Creating Thread Â§ Terminologies Â§ Thread Safety (çº¿ç¨‹å®‰å…¨) Â§ A piece of code that functions correctly during simultaneous execution by multiple Thread accessing the a shared resource without Race Condition (ç«æ€æ¡ä»¶) and Deadlock (æ­»é”) etc Multi-threaded Chip Â§ Control Unit, Registers & Pipeline are replicated .

item.title: Thread
item.description: Abstract Â§ Responsible to carry out some features of a running program - Process Note Thread in a process share the same Address Space Per-process items can be accessed by all Thread 3 ways to implement Â§ User-space Threads (N to 1) Kernel Threads (1 to 1) Hybrid Threads (N to M) Benefits Â§ Fast to create/destroy Â§ 10-100 times faster than Process Because without the need of Expensive Context Switching Makes programming easier Â§ Different parts of program able to communicate without the use of Interrupts (ä¸­æ–­) and Inter-Process Communication (IPC) etc Better responsiveness aka more user friendly Â§ With Multi-threading, each Thread runs for a short while, to make all Threads seem running all the time Example: Powerpoint with Multi-threading Â§ One thread can be used to receive inputs from users One thread can be used to format the slides One thread can be used to save the slides automatically on a regular interval 2 benefits over Process Â§ Lighter to create and destroy compared to Process, because it doesnâ€™t require System Call (ç³»ç»Ÿè°ƒç”¨) to the underlying OS Share memory among themselves, avoid Memory Page Shifting which is expensive Cons Â§ No protection among threads One thread can bring down the entire Process One thread can read, write, or even wipe out another threadâ€™s stack Warning fork() Should we copy over all the threads or just a single one? Warning Signal (Software Interrupt) handling - which thread should handle it Common Procedures Â§ Terminologies Â§ Blocking Â§ Thread doesnâ€™t do anything while waiting for IO Operations or Network Operations etc Non-blocking Â§ Thread carries out other tasks if the current tasks require it to wait for IO Operations or Network Operations etc Goes back to the current task when the waiting ends - Call back However, it still blocks when the task is CPU Bounded .

item.title: Multi-processing
item.description: Abstract Â§ Having multiple Process running at the same time on Multi-core chips, offers true Parallelism(å¹¶è¡Œæ€§) Can avoid issues like Deadlock (æ­»é”) & Race Condition (ç«æ€æ¡ä»¶) faced by Multi-threading effectively but more resource heavy, because not sharing the same Address Space, but independent Address Space comes with a cost Performance limited by the number of CPU cores .

item.title: Asynchronous Single Threading
item.description: Abstract Â§ Basically takes the benefits of Multi-threading without the Cons with Non-blocking Thread Cons Â§ No Parallelism (å¹¶è¡Œæ€§) Â§ Only one single thread, thus canâ€™t take advantage of Multi-core chips Blocking the execution of the program when there is a CPU Bounded task .

item.title: User Thread
item.description: Abstract Â§ Thread managed in the User Space Examples Â§ PThread (C) Â§ A Thread package under Portable Operating System Interface (POSIX) Note pthread_yield() The Library Calls (Library Procedure) for thread to give CPU to other threads In Process, we donâ€™t have this.

item.title: Scheduler Activations
item.description: #os Instead of relying on the Kernel for every thread management decision, the runtime system is responsible for scheduling Thread Mitigate inefficiency from Kernel .

item.title: Process Management
item.description: Abstract Â§ Required in an OS that has multiple Process that want to run at the same, like in the Multi-Programming or Multitasking systems. Because Process unlike Thread will give up its CPU for other Process Components Â§ Process Priority Â§ A value that determines which Process should get executed first Process Scheduler Â§ A program that perform Context Switch of Process based on the Process Priority Linux uses CFS Terminologies Â§ Niceness Â§ An parameter that can be used to adjust the Process Priority for the Process Scheduler In Linux -20 is most not nice 19 is most nice Command to adjust niceness - renice .

item.title: User-space Threads (N to 1)
item.description: #os Put the Thread entirely in User Space The Kernel knows nothing about them As far as the kernel is concerned, it is managing single-threaded Process Thread are implemented by a library The threads run on top of a Runtime-System Each process needs its own private Thread Table When thread becoming blocked locally Thread calls run-time system procedure checks to see if the thread must be put into blocked state.

item.title: Thread Table
item.description: #os Abstract To keep track of the Threads in that Process Similar to Kernelâ€™s Process Table, except that it keeps track only of the per-thread properties Managed by the runtime system in User-space Threads (N to 1) & Kernel in Kernel Threads (1 to 1) .

item.title: Kernel Threads (1 to 1)
item.description: #os Put the Thread entirely in Kernel Space Thread Table inside Kernel When a thread blocks, the Kernel, at its option, can run either another thread from the same Process (if one is ready) or a thread from a different process Pro Â§ Do not require any new, nonblocking System Call (ç³»ç»Ÿè°ƒç”¨) If one thread in a process causes a Page Faults, the kernel can easily check to see if the process has any other runnable threads, and if so, run one of them while waiting for the required page to be brought in from the disk Cons Â§ All calls that might block a Thread are implemented as System Call (ç³»ç»Ÿè°ƒç”¨), at considerably greater cost than a call to a runtime system procedure Relatively greater cost of creating and destroying threads in the kernel Recycle threads When a thread is destroyed, it is marked as not runnable, but its kernel data structures are not otherwise affected When a new thread must be created, an old thread is reactivated, saving some overhead Thread recycling is also possible for user-level threads, but since the thread-management overhead is much smaller, there is less incentive to do this.

item.title: Address Space
item.description: Abstract Â§ A list of memory locations from 0 to some maximum (Virtual Memory), which Process can read & write 3 Components - Stack Segment, Data Segment and Text Segment 3 Components Â§ Stack Segment Â§ Stack (FILO) structure Grows downwards The expansion and shrinking are done automatically Can be used to store function variables XV6-RISCV Kernel Stack Example Â§ // xv6-riscv kernel codes, start.

item.title: Registers
item.description: Abstract Â§ A group of Latch Accessible from Instruction 2 main purposes Â§ Storying values during computations (like Memory Address & value) Configuring CPU Register Type Â§ Instruction Address Register Â§ The register that contains the Memory Address to retrieve the Instruction Instruction Register Â§ Contains Instruction retrieved from Main Memory Control & Status Registers (CSRs) Â§ There are multiple such register Stores information about the current state of the processor or device CSRs are typically used to control various aspects of the processorâ€™s operation, such as interrupt handling, memory management, and power management etc Stack Pointer Â§ Holds the address of the top of the Stack Segment in the current execution context MIPS Registers Â§ Terminologies Â§ Width Â§ The number of Bits inside a register File Â§ A collection of registers that CPU can quickly store and retrieve Data Memory Mapped Â§ Register that is treated as a Main Memory location This means that the register can be accessed using the same Instruction and addressing modes as memory.

item.title: Mathematical Argument
item.description: Abstract Â§ A sequence of Mathematical Statement ending in a Conclusion Every step should follow logically from all previous steps IF (p AND .

item.title: MacOs Setup
item.description: Abstract Â§ Note ğŸŒŸ denotes tools & settings I must have in MacOS to have a smooth user/developer experience GUI Apps Â§ Install Firefox (Replaced with floorp) ğŸŒŸ Install Bypass Paywalls Install Dropbox Install Obsidian ğŸŒŸ Install Keypass (Replaced with Install StrongBox from App Store) ğŸŒŸ Install VSC ğŸŒŸ Add code into cli Install Termius ğŸŒŸ Modify Default Shell Install Tutanota ğŸŒŸ Install Notion ğŸŒŸ Install Docker (Replaced with OrbStack) ğŸŒŸ Install Podman Install Node Version Manager, npm included ğŸŒŸ Install Postman Install GitKraken ğŸŒŸ Install Brave Install MySQL Workbench Install Google Drive Client ğŸŒŸ Install Java JDK ğŸŒŸ Install IntelliJ Community ğŸŒŸ Install VirtualBox Install Ngrok # Move Ngrok Executable to PATH cp ngrok /Users/<USERNAME>/.

item.title: Network Protocol
item.description: Abstract Â§ The Host Host Quote Definites the format and the order of messages exchanged between 2 or more communicating entities, as well as actions taken on the transmission and/or receipt of a message or other event .

item.title: Host
item.description: Abstract Â§ Also known as End System Computers & other devices connected to Internet, thus has a Socket Interface Connected together by a network of Communication Links & Packet Switches Can be identified by Hostname or IP Address 2 types Â§ Client Â§ Desktops, laptops & smartphones, browsers etc Server Â§ Host applications such as web browser program Web servers etc .

item.title: Process
item.description: Abstract Â§ Container that holds all the information needed to run a program, Abstraction over running program 2 Components - Address Space, Process Control Block (PCB) Process usually donâ€™t share Main Memory among themselves for isolation purposes.

item.title: Node.js
item.description: Abstract Â§ Not a Programming Language or Server Is a JavaScript Runtime Environment Terminologies Â§ JavaScript Runtime Environment Â§ A environment to run Javascript, independent of Browser Module Â§ Basically JavaScript Module The methods to be explicitly exposed, there are mainly 3 ways module.

item.title: brk()
item.description: #os Specifies the new Memory Address where the Address Space is to end Not defined in Portable Operating System Interface (POSIX) Programmer encouraged to use malloc .

item.title: Fallacy
item.description: Abstract Â§ Error in reasoning that results in an invalid Mathematical Argument 3 common fallacies causes Using Ambiguous Premises Circular Reasoning (Assuming what is to be proved without having derived it from the Premise) Jumping to a Conclusion Common Errors Â§ Converse Error Â§ Given a -> b is true & b is true, we conclude a is true Going against Modus Tollens Inverse Error Â§ Given a-> b is true & ~a is true, we conclude ~b is true Going against Vacuously True Terminologies Â§.

item.title: Datadog APM
item.description: Abstract Â§ Application Performance Monitoring (APM) Serverless Setup Â§ The example below is based on ECS Fargate The entire setup is around Task Definition, we need to add in 3 parts into it - Pipe application log to AWS Firelens, AWS Firelens and Datadog Agent Sidecar Pipe application log to AWS Firelens Â§ Add the following block inside the application container block Update the highlighted parts with your own values "logConfiguration": { "logDriver": "awsfirelens", "options": { "Host": "http-intake.

item.title: ECS
item.description: Abstract Â§ A lightweight container orchestration service We can mount Volume to it for data that canâ€™t be lost when Container is terminated Components Â§ Container Â§ We can obtain a shell into it using ECS Exec Obtain Private IP of the container, must have curl && jq (JSON Processor) containerPrivateIP=$(curl $ECS_CONTAINER_METADATA_URI | jq -r '.

item.title: Stateless protocol
item.description: #networking Host donâ€™t maintain information about the Host, vice versa Example HTTP Server .

item.title: Internet Protocol (IP)
item.description: #networking Specifies the format of Packet that are sent & received among Routers and Host .

item.title: TCP
item.description: Abstract Â§ Implemented by the OS Kernel Stateful Protocol Lab Â§ Create a TCP Server Â§ Listen on port 8080 over TCP Create a new Process for each new TCP Connection socat - TCP-LISTEN:8080,fork Create a TCP Client Â§ Connect to localhost over port 8080 over TCP telnet 127.

item.title: TCP Connection
item.description: #networking Established after TCP Handshake Resource intensive on both Host & Host side because TCP is Stateful Warm up period To allow TCP to know how much data it can handle Usually browser will keep multiple TCP Connection to the same Host to have a balance between good performance & resource usage(Chrome & Firefox default 6) .

item.title: TLS Certificate
item.description: Abstract Contains the Public Key for Host to encrypt the Symmetric Key used for encrypting all the subsequent data transferring between Host & Host .

item.title: Symmetric Key Exchange
item.description: #networking ##abstract Host uses Public Key in TLS Certificate to encrypt the Symmetric Key Host use its Private Key to decrypt Symmetric Key Now both Host & Host can communicate with each other over Network with data encrypt in-transit with the help of the Symmetric Key In this case, the Symmetric Key also known as Session Key .

item.title: UDP
item.description: Abstract Â§ UDP Server written in NodeJS Benefits Â§ Smaller Packets Â§ No overhead to implement Benefits Less Bandwidth Â§ Because Smaller Packets Faster than TCP Â§ No waiting incurred by Benefits Stateless protocol Â§ Entities can communicate without setting up connection first Support Horizontal Scaling Â§ Cons Â§ No Acknowledgment Â§ No Guaranteed Delivery Â§ Connectionless Â§ No Congestion Control Â§ No Ordered Packets Â§ Security Â§ Host has no idea about Host, anyone can communicate with Host, can be attacked by DDoS easily.

item.title: 500 (Internal Server Error)
item.description: #networking Note Some errors on the Host Example Unable to reach data from Database .

item.title: Content-Type
item.description: #networking Telling the Host what is the Object types, so the Object can be better rendered Example content-type: application/pdf The browser is able to open an in-browser pdf reader .

item.title: 502 (Bad Gateway)
item.description: #networking Note Network Gateway unable to fulfil the HTTP Request from the Host Example AWS ALB unable to reach out to the Target Group .

item.title: 301 (Permanent Redirect)
item.description: #networking Note Telling the client (usually a web browser or a web crawler) that the requested resource has moved permanently to a new location Example When Host accessing via HTTP, but Host only want to server via HTTPS .

item.title: 404 (Unfound)
item.description: #networking Note Resources canâ€™t be found on Host .

item.title: 204 (No Content)
item.description: #networking Note Host successfully processed the HTTP Request, but isn't returning any content .

item.title: POST
item.description: #networking Creates new data Each call has a Side-Effect (new data be created) Has a Request Body Parameters in Request Body, Request Header & URL Use cases Create resources on Host like api keys etc .

item.title: PATCH
item.description: #networking Updates existing data Each call has a Side-Effect (data updated) Has a Request Body Parameters in Request Body, Request Header & URL Use cases Update resources created on Host .

item.title: DELETE
item.description: #networking Delete data Each call has a Side-Effect (delete data) Doesn't have a Request Body Parameters in Request Header & URL Use cases Delete resources created on Host .

item.title: HTTP 1.2 Server Push
item.description: #networking Abstract Host push Object it thinks Host need without the need to receiving any specific HTTP Request for the object If Host click the wrong web page, a lot of Object will be received Potential DDoS - one single HTTP Request can trigger multiple HTTP Response .
